Cannabis.note: Cannabis has an unexpectedly strong and somewhat unpredictable synergy with psychedelics.

Amphetamines.note: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

Cocaine.note: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

Tramadol.note: Tramadol is well known to lower seizure threshold and psychedelics also cause occasional seizures.

Cannabis.note: Cannabis has an unexpectedly strong and somewhat unpredictable synergy with psychedelics.

Amphetamines.note: The focus and anxiety caused by stimulants is magnified by psychedelics and results in an increased risk of thought loops

Cocaine.note: The focus and anxiety caused by stimulants is magnified by psychedelics and results in an increased risk of thought loops

Caffeine.note: High doses of caffeine are uncomfortable and this will be magnified by psychedelics

Tramadol.note: This combination can cause seizures due to the lowering of the threshold by tramadol and the potential of mescaline to cause seziures.

5-MeO-xxT.note: The 5-MeO class of tryptamines can be unpredictable in their interactions, particularly increasing the risk of unpleasant physical side effects.

Cannabis.note: Cannabis has an unexpectedly strong and somewhat unpredictable synergy with psychedelics.

Ketamine.note: Ketamine and psychedelics tend to potentiate each other - go slowly.

MXE.note: As an NMDA antagonist MXE potentiates DOx which can be unpleasantly intense

DXM.note: The DOx class as psychedelic stimulants have the potential to mask the effects of DXM and could lead to redosing to an unsafe level. DXM can also potentiate DOx resulting in an unpleasantly intense experience.

PCP.note: Details of this combination are not well understood but PCP generally interacts in an unpredictable manner.

Amphetamines.note: The combined stimulating effects of the two can lead to an uncomfortable body-load, while the focusing effects of amphetamine can easily lead to thought loops. Coming down from amphetamines while the DOx is still active can be quite anxiogenic.

MDMA.note: The combined stimulating effects of the two can be uncomfortable. Coming down on the MDMA while the DOx is still active can be quite anxiogenic.

Cocaine.note: The combined stimulating effects of the two can lead to an uncomfortable body-load, while the focusing effects of cocaine can easily lead to thought loops. Coming down from cocaine while the DOx is still active can be quite anxiogenic

Caffeine.note: High doses of caffeine may cause anxiety which is less manageable when tripping, and since both are stimulating it may cause some physical discomfort.

Alcohol.note: Drinking on stimulants is risky because the sedative effects of the alcohol are  reduced, and these are what the body uses to gauge drunkenness. This typically leads to excessive drinking with greatly reduced inhibitions, high risk of liver damage and increased dehydration. They will also  allow you to drink past a point where you might normally pass out, increasing the risk.

Tramadol.note: Tramadol is well known to lower seizure threshold and psychedelics also cause occasional seizures.

MAOIs.note: MAO-B inhibitors can increase the potency and duration of phenethylamines unpredictably

5-MeO-xxT.note: The 5-MeO class of tryptamines can be unpredictable in their interactions and the NBOMes are known to be unpredictable even alone. This combination is best avoided

Cannabis.note: Cannabis has an unexpectedly strong and somewhat unpredictable synergy with psychedelics.

MXE.note: As an NMDA antagonist MXE potentiates NBOMes which can be unpleasantly intense

Amphetamines.note: Amphetamines and NBOMes both provide considerable stimulation. When combined they can result in tachycardia, hypertension, vasoconstriction and in extreme cases heart failure. The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants are also not good in combination with psychedelics as they can lead to unpleasant thought loops. NBOMes are known to cause seizures and stimulants can increase this risk.

Cocaine.note: Cocaine and NBOMes both provide considerable stimulation. When combined they can result in severe vasoconstriction, tachycardia, hypertension, and in extreme cases heart failure.

Caffeine.note: Caffiene can bring out the natural stimulation from psychedelic drugs to make it uncomfortable. High doses can cause anxiety which is hard to handle while tripping

Tramadol.note: Tramadol is well known to lower seizure threshold and NBOMes have also shown a tendency to cause severe seizures

MAOIs.note: MAO-B inhibitors can increase the potency and duration of phenethylamines unpredictably

5-MeO-xxT.note: The 5-MeO psychedelics can interact unpredictably to potentiate other psychedelics

Amphetamines.note: The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants increase the chance of unpleasant thought loops. The combination is generally uneccessary because of the stimulating effects of psychedelics. Combination of the stimulating effects may be uncomfortable.

5-MeO-xxT.note: Both classes of compounds can be unpredictable alone

Cannabis.note: Cannabis has an unexpectedly strong and somewhat unpredictable synergy with psychedelics.

Amphetamines.note: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences. In extreme cases, they can result in severe vasoconstriction, tachycardia, hypertension, and in extreme cases heart failure.

Cocaine.note: Cocaine and 2c-t-x both provide considerable stimulation. When combined they can result in severe vasoconstriction, tachycardia, hypertension, and in extreme cases heart failure.

Caffeine.note: High doses of caffeine may cause anxiety which is less manageable when tripping, and since both are stimulating the combination may cause some physical discomfort.

Alcohol.note: Both these classes of compound can interact unpredictably. Caution should be exercised.

Opioids.note: No expected interactions, some opioids have serotonin action, and could lead to Serotonin Syndrome or a seizure. These are pretty much only to Pentazocine, Methadone, Tramadol, Tapenatdol.

MAOIs.note: MAO-B inhibitors can increase the potency and duration of phenethylamines unpredictably, which could be dangerous given the unpredictability of the 2C-T-x series

Cannabis.note: Cannabis has an unexpectedly strong and somewhat unpredictable synergy with psychedelics. Small amounts can reduce nausea with aMT but take care.

Caffeine.note: High doses of caffeine may cause anxiety which is less manageable when tripping, and since both are stimulating the combination may cause some physical discomfort.

Alcohol.note: aMT has a broad mechanism of action in the brain and so does alcohol so the combination can be unpredictable

MAOIs.note: aMT is an MAOI on its own. Using enzyme inhibitors can greatly reduce predictability of effects.

Mescaline.note: The 5-MeO class of tryptamines can be unpredictable in their interactions

DOx.note: The 5-MeO class of tryptamines can be unpredictable in their interactions, particularly increasing the risk of unpleasant physical side effects.

NBOMes.note: The 5-MeO class of tryptamines can be unpredictable in their interactions and the NBOMes are known to be unpredictable even alone. This combination is best avoided

2C-x.note: The 5-MeO psychedelics can interact unpredictably to potentiate other psychedelics

2C-T-x.note: Both classes of compounds can be unpredictable alone

MXE.note: Little information exists about this combination.

Alcohol.note: In excess, this combination can cause nausea.

DOx.note: Ketamine and psychedelics tend to potentiate each other - go slowly.

Amphetamines.note: No unexpected interactions, though likely to increase blood pressure but not an issue with sensible doses. Moving around on high doses of this combination may be ill advised due to risk of physical injury.

MDMA.note: No unexpected interactions, though likely to increase blood pressure  but not an issue with sensible doses. Moving around on high doses of  this combination may be ill advised due to risk of physical injury.

Cocaine.note: No unexpected interactions, though likely to increase blood pressure but not an issue with sensible doses. Moving around on high doses of this combination may be ill advised due to risk of physical injury.

Alcohol.note: Both substances cause ataxia and bring a very high risk of vomiting and unconsciousness. If the user falls unconscious while under the influence there is a severe risk of vomit aspiration if they are not placed in the recovery position.

GHB/GBL.note: Both substances cause ataxia and bring a risk of vomiting and unconsciousness. If the user falls unconscious while under the influence there is a severe risk of vomit aspiration if they are not placed in the recovery position.

Opioids.note: Both substances bring a risk of vomiting and unconsciousness. If the user falls unconscious while under the influence there is a severe risk of vomit aspiration if they are not placed in the recovery position.

Benzodiazepines.note: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position.

MAOIs.note: MAO-B inhibitors appear to increase the potency of Ketamine. MAO-A inhbitors have some negative reports associated with the combination but there isn't much information available

DOx.note: As an NMDA antagonist MXE potentiates DOx which can be unpleasantly intense

NBOMes.note: As an NMDA antagonist MXE potentiates NBOMes which can be unpleasantly intense

5-MeO-xxT.note: Little information exists about this combination.

PCP.note: There are no reports available about this combination

Amphetamines.note: Risk of tachycardia, hypertension, and manic states

MDMA.note: There have been reports of risky serotonergic interactions when the two are taken at the same time, but MXE taken to the end of an MDMA experience does not appear to cause the same issues.

Cocaine.note: Stimulants taken with MXE can lead to hypermanic states much more easily, especially if sleep is avoided.

Alcohol.note: There is a high risk of memory loss, vomiting and severe ataxia from this combination.

GHB/GBL.note: Both substances cause ataxia and bring a risk of vomiting and unconsciousness. If the patient falls unconscious while under the influence there is a severe risk of vomit aspiration if they are not placed in the recovery position.

Opioids.note: This combination can potentiate the effects of the opioid

Benzodiazepines.note: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. Place affected patients in the recovery position to prevent vomit aspiration from excess.

SSRIs.note: Depending on the SSRI this combination can be unpredictable

DOx.note: The DOx class as psychedelic stimulants have the potential to mask the effects of DXM and could lead to redosing to an unsafe level. DXM can also potentiate DOx resulting in an unpleasantly intense experience.

5-MeO-xxT.note: Little information exists about this combination.

Amphetamines.note: Both substances raise heart rate, in extreme cases, panic attacks caused by these drugs have led to more serious heart issues.

Cocaine.note: Both substances raise heart rate, in extreme cases, panic attacks caused by these drugs have led to more serious heart issues

Caffeine.note: High doses of caffeine may cause anxiety which is less manageable when tripping, and since both are stimulating the combination may cause some physical discomfort.

Alcohol.note: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. Place affected patients in the recovery position to prevent vomit aspiration from excess. Additionally CNS depression can lead to difficulty breathing. Avoid on anything higher than 1st plateau.

GHB/GBL.note: Both substances cause ataxia and bring a risk of vomiting and unconsciousness. If the patient falls unconscious while under the influence there is a severe risk of vomit aspiration if they are not placed in the recovery position. This combination is hard to predict

Opioids.note: CNS depression, difficult breathing, heart issues, hepatoxic, just very unsafe combination all around. Additionally if one takes dxm, their tolerance of opiates goes down slightly, thus causing additional synergistic effects.

Benzodiazepines.note: Small doses of benzos can end a bad trip, but both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and this can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position.

DOx.note: Details of this combination are not well understood but PCP generally interacts in an unpredictable manner.

MXE.note: There are no reports available about this combination

LSD.note: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

DMT.note: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

Mescaline.note: The focus and anxiety caused by stimulants is magnified by psychedelics and results in an increased risk of thought loops

DOx.note: The combined stimulating effects of the two can lead to an uncomfortable body-load, while the focusing effects of amphetamine can easily lead to thought loops. Coming down from amphetamines while the DOx is still active can be quite anxiogenic.

NBOMes.note: Amphetamines and NBOMes both provide considerable stimulation. When combined they can result in tachycardia, hypertension, vasoconstriction and in extreme cases heart failure. The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants are also not good in combination with psychedelics as they can lead to unpleasant thought loops. NBOMes are known to cause seizures and stimulants can increase this risk.

2C-x.note: The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants increase the chance of unpleasant thought loops. The combination is generally uneccessary because of the stimulating effects of psychedelics. Combination of the stimulating effects may be uncomfortable.

2C-T-x.note: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences. In extreme cases, they can result in severe vasoconstriction, tachycardia, hypertension, and in extreme cases heart failure.

5-MeO-xxT.note: The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants increase the chance of unpleasant thought loops. The combination is generally unnecessary because of the stimulating effects of psychedelics.

Cannabis.note: Stimulants increase anxiety levels and the risk of thought loops which can lead to negative experiences

Ketamine.note: No unexpected interactions, though likely to increase blood pressure but not an issue with sensible doses. Moving around on high doses of this combination may be ill advised due to risk of physical injury.

MXE.note: Risk of tachycardia, hypertension, and manic states

DXM.note: Both substances raise heart rate, in extreme cases, panic attacks caused by these drugs have led to more serious heart issues.

PCP.note: This combination can easily lead to hypermanic states

MDMA.note: Amphetamines increase the neurotoxic effects of MDMA

Cocaine.note: This combination of stimulants will increase strain on the heart. It is not generally worth it as cocaine has a mild blocking effect on dopamine releasers like amphetamine

Caffeine.note: This combination of stimulants is not generally necessary and may increase strain on the heart, as well as potentially causing anxiety and greater physical discomfort.

Alcohol.note: Drinking on stimulants is risky because the sedative effects of the alcohol are reduced, and these are what the body uses to gauge drunkenness. This typically leads to excessive drinking with greatly reduced inhibitions, high risk of liver damage and increased dehydration. They will also allow you to drink past a point where you might normally pass out, increasing the risk. If you do decide to do this then you should set a limit of how much you will drink each hour and stick to it, bearing in mind that you will feel the alcohol and the stimulant less. Extended release formulations may severely impede sleep, further worsening the hangover.

GHB/GBL.note: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of sedatives. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

Opioids.note: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

Tramadol.note: Tramadol and stimulants both increase the risk of seizures.

Benzodiazepines.note: Both can dull each other's effects, so if one wears off before the other it's possible to overdose due to the lack of counteraction

MAOIs.note: MAO-B inhibitors can increase the potency and duration of phenethylamines unpredictably. MAO-A inhibitors with amphetamine can lead to hypertensive crises.

DOx.note: The combined stimulating effects of the two can be uncomfortable. Coming down on the MDMA while the DOx is still active can be quite anxiogenic.

5-MeO-xxT.note: Some of the 5-MeO tryptamines are a bit unpredictable and should be mixed with MDMA with care

Cannabis.note: Large amounts of cannabis may cause strong and somewhat unpredictable experiences in combination with MDMA. Cannabis should be saved for towards the end of the experience if possible.

Ketamine.note: No unexpected interactions, though likely to increase blood pressure  but not an issue with sensible doses. Moving around on high doses of  this combination may be ill advised due to risk of physical injury.

MXE.note: There have been reports of risky serotonergic interactions when the two are taken at the same time, but MXE taken to the end of an MDMA experience does not appear to cause the same issues.

PCP.note: This combination can easily lead to hypermanic states

Amphetamines.note: Amphetamines increase the neurotoxic effects of MDMA

Cocaine.note: Cocaine blocks some of the desirable effects of MDMA while increasing the risk of heart attack.

Caffeine.note: Caffiene is not really necessary with MDMA and increases any neurotoxic effects from MDMA

Alcohol.note: Both MDMA and alcohol cause dehydration. Approach this combination with caution, moderation and sufficient hydration. More than a small amount of alcohol will dull the euphoria of MDMA

GHB/GBL.note: Large amounts of GHB/GBL may overwhelm the effects of MDMA on the comedown.

Tramadol.note: Tramadol and stimulants both increase the risk of seizures.

MAOIs.note: MAO-B inhibitors can increase the potency and duration of  phenethylamines unpredictably. MAO-A inhibitors with MDMA will lead to hypertensive crises.

NBOMes.note: Cocaine and NBOMes both provide considerable stimulation. When combined they can result in severe vasoconstriction, tachycardia, hypertension, and in extreme cases heart failure.

2C-x.note: The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants increase the chance of unpleasant thought loops. The combination is generally unnecessary because of the stimulating effects of psychedelics. Combination of the stimulating effects may be uncomfortable.

2C-T-x.note: Cocaine and 2c-t-x both provide considerable stimulation. When combined they can result in severe vasoconstriction, tachycardia, hypertension, and in extreme cases heart failure.

5-MeO-xxT.note: The anxiogenic and focusing effects of stimulants increase the chance of unpleasant thought loops. The combination is generally unnecessary because of the stimulating effects of psychedelics.

Ketamine.note: No unexpected interactions, though likely to increase blood pressure but not an issue with sensible doses. Moving around on high doses of this combination may be ill advised due to risk of physical injury.

DXM.note: Both substances raise heart rate, in extreme cases, panic attacks caused by these drugs have led to more serious heart issues

PCP.note: This combination can easily lead to hypermanic states

Amphetamines.note: This combination of stimulants will increase strain on the heart. It is not generally worth it as cocaine has a mild blocking effect on dopamine releasers like amphetamine

MDMA.note: Cocaine blocks some of the desirable effects of MDMA while increasing the risk of heart attack.

Caffeine.note: Both stimulants, risk of tachycardia, hypertension, and in extreme cases heart failure.

Alcohol.note: Drinking on stimulants is risky because the sedative effects of the alcohol are reduced, and these are what the body uses to gauge drunkenness. This typically leads to excessive drinking with greatly reduced inhibitions, high risk of liver damage and increased dehydration. They will also allow you to drink past a point where you might normally pass out, increasing the risk. If you do decide to do this then you should set a limit of how much you will drink each hour and stick to it, bearing in mind that you will feel the alcohol less. Cocaine is potentiated somewhat by alcohol because of the formation of cocaethylene.

GHB/GBL.note: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of sedatives. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest. Likewise the G can wear off and leave a dangerous concentration of cocaine behind

Opioids.note: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

Tramadol.note: Tramadol and stimulants both increase the risk of seizures.

SSRIs.note: May reduce each others' effectiveness. Cocaine can reduce mental stability and therefore exacerbate conditions which SSRIs are used to treat.

Mescaline.note: High doses of caffeine are uncomfortable and this will be magnified by psychedelics

DOx.note: High doses of caffeine may cause anxiety which is less manageable when tripping, and since both are stimulating it may cause some physical discomfort.

NBOMes.note: Caffiene can bring out the natural stimulation from psychedelic drugs to make it uncomfortable. High doses can cause anxiety which is hard to handle while tripping

2C-x.note: High doses of caffeine may cause anxiety which is less manageable when tripping, and since both are stimulating the combination may cause some physical discomfort.

PCP.note: Details of this combination are not well understood but PCP generally interacts in an unpredictable manner.

Amphetamines.note: This combination of stimulants is not generally necessary and may increase strain on the heart, as well as potentially causing anxiety and greater physical discomfort.

MDMA.note: Caffiene is not really necessary with MDMA and increases any neurotoxic effects from MDMA

Cocaine.note: Both stimulants, risk of tachycardia, hypertension, and in extreme cases heart failure.

DOx.note: Drinking on stimulants is risky because the sedative effects of the alcohol are  reduced, and these are what the body uses to gauge drunkenness. This typically leads to excessive drinking with greatly reduced inhibitions, high risk of liver damage and increased dehydration. They will also  allow you to drink past a point where you might normally pass out, increasing the risk.

2C-T-x.note: Both these classes of compound can interact unpredictably. Caution should be exercised.

aMT.note: aMT has a broad mechanism of action in the brain and so does alcohol so the combination can be unpredictable

Cannabis.note: In excess, this combination can cause nausea.

Ketamine.note: Both substances cause ataxia and bring a very high risk of vomiting and unconsciousness. If the user falls unconscious while under the influence there is a severe risk of vomit aspiration if they are not placed in the recovery position.

MXE.note: There is a high risk of memory loss, vomiting and severe ataxia from this combination.

DXM.note: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. Place affected patients in the recovery position to prevent vomit aspiration from excess. Additionally CNS depression can lead to difficulty breathing. Avoid on anything higher than 1st plateau.

PCP.note: Details of this combination are not well understood but PCP generally interacts in an unpredictable manner.

Nitrous.note: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position. Memory blackouts are likely.

Amphetamines.note: Drinking on stimulants is risky because the sedative effects of the alcohol are reduced, and these are what the body uses to gauge drunkenness. This typically leads to excessive drinking with greatly reduced inhibitions, high risk of liver damage and increased dehydration. They will also allow you to drink past a point where you might normally pass out, increasing the risk. If you do decide to do this then you should set a limit of how much you will drink each hour and stick to it, bearing in mind that you will feel the alcohol and the stimulant less. Extended release formulations may severely impede sleep, further worsening the hangover.

MDMA.note: Both MDMA and alcohol cause dehydration. Approach this combination with caution, moderation and sufficient hydration. More than a small amount of alcohol will dull the euphoria of MDMA

Cocaine.note: Drinking on stimulants is risky because the sedative effects of the alcohol are reduced, and these are what the body uses to gauge drunkenness. This typically leads to excessive drinking with greatly reduced inhibitions, high risk of liver damage and increased dehydration. They will also allow you to drink past a point where you might normally pass out, increasing the risk. If you do decide to do this then you should set a limit of how much you will drink each hour and stick to it, bearing in mind that you will feel the alcohol less. Cocaine is potentiated somewhat by alcohol because of the formation of cocaethylene.

GHB/GBL.note: Even in very low doses this combination rapidly leads to memory loss, severe ataxia and unconsciousness. There is a high risk of vomit aspiration while unconscious.

Opioids.note: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. Place affected patients in the recovery position to prevent vomit aspiration from excess. Memory blackouts are likely

Tramadol.note: Heavy CNS depressants, risk of seizures. Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. Place affected patients in the recovery position to prevent vomit aspiration from excess. Memory blackouts are likely.

Benzodiazepines.note: Ethanol ingestion may potentiate the CNS effects of many benzodiazepines. The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position. Blacking out and memory loss is almost certain.

MAOIs.note: Tyramine found in many alcoholic beverages can have dangerous reactions with MAOIs, causing an increase in blood pressure.

SSRIs.note: Alcohol may potentiate some of the pharmacologic effects of CNS-active agents. Use in combination may result in additive central nervous system depression and/or impairment of judgment, thinking, and  psychomotor skills.

Ketamine.note: Both substances cause ataxia and bring a risk of vomiting and unconsciousness. If the user falls unconscious while under the influence there is a severe risk of vomit aspiration if they are not placed in the recovery position.

MXE.note: Both substances cause ataxia and bring a risk of vomiting and unconsciousness. If the patient falls unconscious while under the influence there is a severe risk of vomit aspiration if they are not placed in the recovery position.

DXM.note: Both substances cause ataxia and bring a risk of vomiting and unconsciousness. If the patient falls unconscious while under the influence there is a severe risk of vomit aspiration if they are not placed in the recovery position. This combination is hard to predict

PCP.note: Details of this combination are not well understood but PCP generally interacts in an unpredictable manner.

Nitrous.note: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position. Memory blackouts are likely.

Amphetamines.note: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of sedatives. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

MDMA.note: Large amounts of GHB/GBL may overwhelm the effects of MDMA on the comedown.

Cocaine.note: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of sedatives. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest. Likewise the G can wear off and leave a dangerous concentration of cocaine behind

Alcohol.note: Even in very low doses this combination rapidly leads to memory loss, severe ataxia and unconsciousness. There is a high risk of vomit aspiration while unconscious.

Opioids.note: The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position

Tramadol.note: The sedative effects of this combination can lead to dangerous respiratory depression.

Benzodiazepines.note: The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position.

2C-T-x.note: No expected interactions, some opioids have serotonin action, and could lead to Serotonin Syndrome or a seizure. These are pretty much only to Pentazocine, Methadone, Tramadol, Tapenatdol.

Ketamine.note: Both substances bring a risk of vomiting and unconsciousness. If the user falls unconscious while under the influence there is a severe risk of vomit aspiration if they are not placed in the recovery position.

MXE.note: This combination can potentiate the effects of the opioid

DXM.note: CNS depression, difficult breathing, heart issues, hepatoxic, just very unsafe combination all around. Additionally if one takes dxm, their tolerance of opiates goes down slightly, thus causing additional synergistic effects.

PCP.note: PCP can reduce opioid tolerance, increasing the risk of overdose

Nitrous.note: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position. Memory blackouts are likely.

Amphetamines.note: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

Cocaine.note: Stimulants increase respiration rate allowing a higher dose of opiates. If the stimulant wears off first then the opiate may overcome the patient and cause respiratory arrest.

Alcohol.note: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. Place affected patients in the recovery position to prevent vomit aspiration from excess. Memory blackouts are likely

GHB/GBL.note: The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position

Tramadol.note: Concomitant use of tramadol increases the seizure risk in patients taking other opioids. These agents are often individually epileptogenic and may have additive effects on seizure threshold during coadministration. Central nervous system- and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present

Benzodiazepines.note: Central nervous system and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present. The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position Blackouts/memory loss likely

MAOIs.note: Coadministration of monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) with certain opioids has been associated with rare reports of severe and fatal adverse reactions. There appear to be two types of interaction, an excitatory and a depressive one. Symptoms of the excitatory reaction may include agitation, headache, diaphoresis, hyperpyrexia, flushing, shivering, myoclonus, rigidity, tremor, diarrhea, hypertension, tachycardia, seizures, and coma. Death has occurred in some cases.

SSRIs.note: There have been very infrequent reports of a risk of serotonin syndrome with this combination, though this should not be a practical concern.

Mushrooms.note: Tramadol is well known to lower seizure threshold and psychedelics also cause occasional seizures.

LSD.note: Tramadol is well known to lower seizure threshold and psychedelics also cause occasional seizures.

DMT.note: Tramadol is well known to lower seizure threshold and psychedelics also cause occasional seizures.

Mescaline.note: This combination can cause seizures due to the lowering of the threshold by tramadol and the potential of mescaline to cause seziures.

DOx.note: Tramadol is well known to lower seizure threshold and psychedelics also cause occasional seizures.

NBOMes.note: Tramadol is well known to lower seizure threshold and NBOMes have also shown a tendency to cause severe seizures

2C-x.note: Tramadol is well known to lower seizure threshold and psychedelics raise the risk of seizures.

Nitrous.note: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position. Memory blackouts are likely.

Amphetamines.note: Tramadol and stimulants both increase the risk of seizures.

MDMA.note: Tramadol and stimulants both increase the risk of seizures.

Cocaine.note: Tramadol and stimulants both increase the risk of seizures.

Alcohol.note: Heavy CNS depressants, risk of seizures. Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. Place affected patients in the recovery position to prevent vomit aspiration from excess. Memory blackouts are likely.

GHB/GBL.note: The sedative effects of this combination can lead to dangerous respiratory depression.

Opioids.note: Concomitant use of tramadol increases the seizure risk in patients taking other opioids. These agents are often individually epileptogenic and may have additive effects on seizure threshold during coadministration. Central nervous system- and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present

Benzodiazepines.note: Central nervous system- and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present. Vomit aspiration a risk when passed out, lay down in recovery position if ingested.

Ketamine.note: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position.

MXE.note: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. Place affected patients in the recovery position to prevent vomit aspiration from excess.

DXM.note: Small doses of benzos can end a bad trip, but both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and this can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position.

PCP.note: Both substances potentiate the ataxia and sedation caused by the other and can lead to unexpected loss of consciousness at high doses. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position. Memory blackouts are likely

Amphetamines.note: Both can dull each other's effects, so if one wears off before the other it's possible to overdose due to the lack of counteraction

Alcohol.note: Ethanol ingestion may potentiate the CNS effects of many benzodiazepines. The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position. Blacking out and memory loss is almost certain.

GHB/GBL.note: The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position.

Opioids.note: Central nervous system and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present. The two substances potentiate each other strongly and unpredictably, very rapidly leading to unconsciousness. While unconscious, vomit aspiration is a risk if not placed in the recovery position Blackouts/memory loss likely

Tramadol.note: Central nervous system- and/or respiratory-depressant effects may be additively or synergistically present. Vomit aspiration a risk when passed out, lay down in recovery position if ingested.

DOx.note: MAO-B inhibitors can increase the potency and duration of phenethylamines unpredictably

NBOMes.note: MAO-B inhibitors can increase the potency and duration of phenethylamines unpredictably

2C-x.note: MAO-B inhibitors can increase the potency and duration of phenethylamines unpredictably

2C-T-x.note: MAO-B inhibitors can increase the potency and duration of phenethylamines unpredictably, which could be dangerous given the unpredictability of the 2C-T-x series

aMT.note: aMT is an MAOI on its own. Using enzyme inhibitors can greatly reduce predictability of effects.

Ketamine.note: MAO-B inhibitors appear to increase the potency of Ketamine. MAO-A inhbitors have some negative reports associated with the combination but there isn't much information available

MXE.note: MAO-B inhibitors appear to increase the potency of MXE. MAO-A inhbitors have some negative reports associated with the combination but there isn't much information available

PCP.note: This combination is very poorly explored

Amphetamines.note: MAO-B inhibitors can increase the potency and duration of phenethylamines unpredictably. MAO-A inhibitors with amphetamine can lead to hypertensive crises.

MDMA.note: MAO-B inhibitors can increase the potency and duration of  phenethylamines unpredictably. MAO-A inhibitors with MDMA will lead to hypertensive crises.

Cocaine.note: This combination is poorly explored

Alcohol.note: Tyramine found in many alcoholic beverages can have dangerous reactions with MAOIs, causing an increase in blood pressure.

Opioids.note: Coadministration of monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) with certain opioids has been associated with rare reports of severe and fatal adverse reactions. There appear to be two types of interaction, an excitatory and a depressive one. Symptoms of the excitatory reaction may include agitation, headache, diaphoresis, hyperpyrexia, flushing, shivering, myoclonus, rigidity, tremor, diarrhea, hypertension, tachycardia, seizures, and coma. Death has occurred in some cases.

MXE.note: Depending on the SSRI this combination can be unpredictable

PCP.note: Details of this combination are not well understood but PCP generally interacts in an unpredictable manner.

Cocaine.note: May reduce each others' effectiveness. Cocaine can reduce mental stability and therefore exacerbate conditions which SSRIs are used to treat.

Alcohol.note: Alcohol may potentiate some of the pharmacologic effects of CNS-active agents. Use in combination may result in additive central nervous system depression and/or impairment of judgment, thinking, and  psychomotor skills.

Opioids.note: There have been very infrequent reports of a risk of serotonin syndrome with this combination, though this should not be a practical concern.
